description.en: An ontology to describe the operations of the Survival International NGO

comment.en: Tribe living in a forest
An island is a portion of land entirely surrounded by water
The continent of Asia
The European continent
The African continent
The South American continent
The Antarctic continent
The North American continent
The continent of Oceania
One of the seven geographical regions that make up the global landmass
A local office or branch of an organization. Can be an indipendent legal entity or not.
A campaign directly helping one or more specific tribes
An island mostly covered by forests

Deforestation or forest clearance is the removal of a forest or stand of trees from land that is then converted to non-forest use. Deforestation can involve conversion of forest land to farms, ranches, or urban use. The most concentrated deforestation occurs in tropical rainforests.

Illegal fishing takes place when vessels or poachers operate in violation of the laws and especially in protected natural reserves. It endangers some tribes by reducing their sources of livelihood and exposing them to deadly deseases.

Colonial conservation, also known as Fortress Conservation, rests on the racist misconception that indigenous people cannot be trusted to look after their own land and the animals that live there. Its proponents view the original custodians of the land as a “nuisance” to be “dealt with", instead of as experts in local biodiversity and key partners in conservation.
Illegal mining is mining activity that is undertaken without state permission, in particular in absence of land rights, mining licenses, and exploration or mineral transportation permits.

Forced contact is the practice of contacting forcibly indigenous tribes for many reasons such as to either exploit their land, convert them to Christianity or simply study their habits. Whole populations are being wiped out by genocidal violence, and by diseases like flu and measles to which they have no resistance.
A generic threat which may endanger one or more tribe or a tribe-specific threat

Tribe that has never, or nearly never, been contacted by the "civilized" world, if not for some forced contacts, which have almost always been rejected. Little or nothing is known about these tribes, sometimes just their name or not event that.
Tribe living in a desert
The Yanomami are the largest relatively isolated tribe in South America. They live in the rainforests and mountains of northern Brazil and southern Venezuela.

Matsés are one of the uncontacted tribes living in the Amazon Uncontacted Frontier. Not much is known about them. But we do know that they have rejected contact, often as a result of horrific violence and diseases brought in by outsiders.
The Sentinelese are an uncontacted tribe living on North Sentinal Island, one of the Andaman Islands in the Indian Ocean. They vigorously reject all contact with outsiders.
The Bushmen are the indigenous peoples of southern Africa. Largely hunter-gatherers, their territory spans several nations and they have called the region home for tens of thousands of years.

Mashco-Piro are one of the uncontacted tribes living in the Amazon Uncontacted Frontier. Not much is known about them. But we do know that they have rejected contact, often as a result of horrific violence and diseases brought in by outsiders.
Endangered tribes and indigenous peoples

Well known conservation groups like WWF, WCS, and African Parks have been aware of these atrocities for many years but they continue to fund and support colonial conservation. For over 30 years, Survival has been campaigning against the atrocities committed in the name of “conservation”.

There are more than a hundred uncontacted tribes around the world. They are a vitally important part of humankind’s diversity, but they face catastrophe unless their land is protected. Survival is doing everything possible to secure their land for them, and to let them live.

President Jair Bolsonaro is trying to turn back the clock on indigenous rights. He wants to strip their autonomy, sell off their territories for logging and mining and “assimilate” them against their wishes. Brazil’s indigenous peoples, their supporters and allies, and Survival International are fighting back as the President plots to steal their land, destroy their lives and annihilate them as peoples.
A generic project intended to mobilize public support and use democratic tools, such as lobbying, addressing some threats, in order to help endangered tribes
Tribe living on one or more islands
The Bolivarian Republic of Venezuela
The United States of America
The Republic of Botswana
The Italian Republic
The United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
The Plurinational State of Bolivia
The Republic of Peru
The Republic of India
A distinct territorial body or political entity
An island mostly covered by a desert area
North Sentinel Island is one of the Andaman Islands, an Indian archipelago in the Bay of Bengal

The Yanomami Park covers 37,000 square miles in the Brazilian Amazon on the Venezuelan border; it is inhabited by 27,000 Yanomami. The Yanomami Park in Brazil was created on 25 May 1992, following years of campaigning by Davi Kopenawa Yanomami, Survival International, and the Pro Yanomami Commission.
Central Kalahari Game Reserve is an extensive national park in the Kalahari Desert of Botswana
Straddling the borders of Peru, Brazil and Bolivia is the Uncontacted Frontier, home to more uncontacted tribes than anywhere else on the planet
A geographical region which may span one or more countries, hosting one or more tribes
A forest is an area of land dominated by trees
A desert is a arid or semi-arid area of landscape
A generic location
Brazilian office of Survival International

The Articulation of Indigenous Peoples of Brazil was created by the indigenous movement at Camp Terra Livre (ATL) 2005. APIB is an instance of national reference of the indigenous movement in Brazil, created from the bottom up.

labels.en: Articulation of Indigenous Peoples of Brazil
labels.it: Articolazione dei Popoli Indigeni del Brasile

comment.en: Survival International is a human rights organisation formed in 1969 that campaigns for the rights of indigenous and/or tribal peoples and uncontacted peoples
US office of Survival International
Italian office of Survival International
An organization is an entity, such as a company, an institution, or an association, comprising one or more people and having a particular purpose
A campaign led by more than one organization
